title: Communication Techniques
summary: Use open, supportive communication to help your teen feel understood and safe.

details.content: Effective communication builds trust, reduces misunderstandings, and helps teens express their anxieties without fear of judgment.
Instead of dismissing your teen’s worries, you listen attentively, validate their feelings, and ask open-ended questions to encourage sharing.

content: Use active listening—maintain eye contact and avoid interrupting.
Reflect back what you hear to show understanding.
Validate your teen’s feelings, even if you don’t agree.
Ask open-ended questions to encourage discussion.
Avoid criticism or minimizing their concerns.

title: Cognitive Behavioral Strategies
summary: Help your teen identify and challenge anxious thoughts and replace them with more balanced thinking.

details.content: Anxious teens often get stuck in negative thinking patterns. Cognitive behavioral strategies teach them to recognize and reframe these thoughts, reducing anxiety.

Your teen worries about failing a test. You help them identify the thought ('I’ll fail and ruin my future'), examine the evidence, and develop a more realistic perspective ('I’ve studied and can do my best').

content: Teach your teen to notice automatic negative thoughts.
Help them question the evidence for and against these thoughts.
Encourage them to come up with more balanced alternatives.
Practice thought-challenging together after anxious situations.
Model flexible thinking in your own life.

title: Mindfulness Practices
summary: Encourage your teen to use mindfulness to stay present and reduce anxiety.

details.content: Mindfulness helps teens observe their thoughts and feelings without judgment, making it easier to manage anxiety and avoid getting overwhelmed.
When your teen feels anxious before a presentation, you guide them through a short breathing exercise to help them focus on the present moment.

content: Practice mindful breathing together for a few minutes daily.
Encourage noticing sensations, sounds, and sights in the environment.
Use guided mindfulness apps or recordings.
Remind your teen to bring attention back to the present when anxious.
Model mindfulness by taking pauses and being present yourself.

title: Building Resilience
summary: Support your teen in developing coping skills and confidence to handle challenges.

details.content: Resilience helps teens bounce back from setbacks and face fears, reducing the impact of anxiety over time.
After a disappointing grade, you help your teen reflect on what they learned and encourage them to try again, reinforcing their ability to cope.

content: Praise effort and persistence, not just outcomes.
Encourage problem-solving and brainstorming solutions.
Share stories of overcoming challenges.
Help your teen set realistic goals and celebrate progress.
Allow your teen to experience manageable failures and learn from them.

title: Setting Boundaries
summary: Establish healthy boundaries to support your teen’s independence and reduce enabling behaviors.

details.content: Clear boundaries help teens develop autonomy and learn to manage anxiety without excessive parental intervention.
Instead of completing your teen’s homework when they feel anxious, you encourage them to try on their own and offer support if needed.

content: Communicate expectations and limits clearly and calmly.
Avoid rescuing your teen from every anxious situation.
Encourage your teen to take age-appropriate risks.
Be consistent with rules and consequences.
Model healthy boundaries in your own relationships.

title: Encouraging Healthy Habits
summary: Promote routines and habits that support your teen’s physical and emotional well-being.

details.content: Good sleep, nutrition, exercise, and self-care reduce vulnerability to anxiety and improve mood regulation.
You help your teen create a bedtime routine and encourage regular physical activity to support their mental health.

content: Encourage regular sleep and wake times.
Promote balanced meals and hydration.
Support daily physical activity.
Limit screen time before bed.
Model self-care and healthy routines yourself.

title: Seeking Professional Help
summary: Recognize when to involve mental health professionals to support your teen’s anxiety.

details.content: Some anxiety requires specialized treatment. Professional help can provide therapy, guidance, and resources for your teen and family.
When your teen’s anxiety interferes with daily life, you consult a therapist who specializes in adolescent anxiety.

content: Watch for signs that anxiety is persistent or worsening.
Discuss the idea of therapy openly and without stigma.
Research qualified mental health professionals together.
Support your teen in attending appointments.
Stay involved in treatment as appropriate.
